section.title: Tuple Values
section.para:
Orc's Tuple data type is a sequence of values, whose number of values is at least two. (Orc does not provide for the construction of "0-tuples" or "1-tuples".) Tuples vary from lists in two significant ways:
Tuples are intended to be used where they have a fixed length. Lists may have varying lengths.
Tuples may have elements of varying types in each position. Lists must be of a uniform type (though this may be Top).
Although one can explicitly project a tuple element by its index, it is idiomatic, safer, and far more common to use pattern matching to extract tuple elements.

section.title: Constructors
section.para: A tuple is written as two or more expressions, separated by commas and enclosed within parentheses. Evaluation of the tuple expression (e_1, ..., e_n) reaps each ei to a value vi and publishes the tuple value (v_1, ..., v_n).

section.title: Operations
section.para:
Notable tuple operations include:
Projection: tuple( index )
Project first element of pair: fst
Project second element of pair: snd

section.title: Java calls
section.para: Orc Tuples don't correspond to any Java value, so if a Tuple is passed to Java code, it will be as a java.lang.Object of a type not specified here.

example.title: Tuple Selection
example.programlisting: {- Creates a new tuple where both values are the same as the first in "a", then publishes the second value of the new tuple, which is 1 -} val a = (1,2) fst(a) >x> (x,x) >b> snd(b)
